title: Where’s the snow? N.J. is having a January snow drought, and we’re not alone.
summary:
New Jersey’s main weather reporting station — Newark Liberty International Airport — normally gets about 8 inches of snow in January, but has gotten only 2.7 inches so far this month.
In Central New Jersey, New Brunswick normally gets 8 inches of snow in January, but has measured a measly 1 inch so far this month.
Down south, Atlantic City International Airport usually gets 4.5 inches of snow in January, but has gotten just a trace of snow so far this month.
Philadelphia has measured only 0.2 inches of snow so far this month, and Allentown — which normally gets a healthy 10 inches of snow in January — has measured only 3.2 inches so far.
Snow lovers might not want to hear this, but some forecasters say the current atmospheric signs are pointing to a lingering snow drought in the New Jersey region.

title: Newark lead levels are lower but still elevated, new water tests show
summary:
Lead levels in Newark’s drinking water remain elevated but dropped slightly in the last six months, the latest sampling shows.
Lead has plagued Newark’s water since 2017.
City officials previously said they expected high lead levels to continue until a new water treatment takes full effect or lead pipes are replaced.
Newark’s water woes escalated this summer when the federal government asked the city to distribute bottled water because a handful of filters meant to keep tap water safe failed to work.
To date, workers have replaced 4,474 lead service lines out of 18,000 in the city, Newark officials confirmed Monday.

title: Here’s where N.J.’s low-snow winter ranks as February fades away
summary:
New Jersey’s strange, almost snowless winter season isn’t over yet.
That distinction belongs to the unrivaled winter of 1972-1973, when only 4 inches of snow fell in the Garden State during the entire snow season — which runs from October through April.
Another low-snow winter occurred in 1918-1919, with just 4.2 inches of frozen precipitation accumulating across the state, according to Robinson.
Although snow has been a rare commodity across the state this winter, it’s been almost non-existent in South Jersey.
“I’m not about to declare the snow season over, as March and early April can see snow,” Robinson said.

title: NJ's Horizon Joins Blue Cross Partnership To Cut Drug Costs
summary:
NEWARK, NJ — A new partnership between 18 Blue Cross Blue Shield health insurers and a nonprofit may bring some financial relief to people paying through the nose for their prescription drugs.
On Thursday, Horizon Blue Cross Blue Shield of New Jersey announced that it is joining 17 other Blue Cross Blue Shield Association members across the nation to form a $55 million subsidiary company with Civica, a nonprofit that manufactures generic drugs in an effort to combat shortages and price spikes in hospitals.
Horizon Blue Cross Blue Shield of New Jersey, a nonprofit health service corporation which is headquartered in Newark, provides coverage to more than 3.6 million people throughout the state.
Prescription drug spending averages more than 22 percent of the insurance premium dollar, Horizon spokespeople said.
Other Blue Cross Blue Shield companies participating in the Civica partnership include Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Alabama, Arkansas Blue Cross and Blue Shield, Blue Shield of California, Capital BlueCross, CareFirst BlueCross BlueShield, Excellus BlueCross BlueShield, Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Hawaii, Highmark Blue Cross Blue Shield, Horizon Blue Cross Blue Shield of New Jersey, Blue Cross of Idaho, Independence Blue Cross, Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Kansas, Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Kansas City, Blue Cross Blue Shield of Michigan, BlueCross BlueShield of Western New York and BlueShield of Northeastern New York, Blue Cross & Blue Shield of Rhode Island, BlueCross BlueShield of South Carolina, Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Vermont and the Blue Cross Blue Shield Association's Federal Employee Program.

title: Newark, Elizabeth year-over-year rent increases slower in March than February
authors: Is The Managing Editor For Njbiz.
summary:
According to RENTCafé’s latest National Monthly Rent Report, the year over year rent increase in March was slower than that of February, reaching an average rate of $1,474.
Newark rents reached an average of $1,212 after a 2.3 percent annual growth, while apartment rates in Elizabeth ($1,295) registered a 5.1 percent annual jump.
Both of these New Jersey renter hotspots saw a slower yearly rent increase in March than in February – Newark 3.2 percent and Elizabeth 5.7 percent –, falling in line with the national slowdown.
Camden apartments saw the second-highest yearly increase, jumping by 8.7 percent and making them $82 more expensive than this time last year.
In March, Jersey City was in the top 5 most expensive small cities for renters nationwide, with an average rent pegged at $2,989 after a 2.5 percent annual increase.

title: Citing Coronavirus, Newark Delays Release Of School Matches For Fall
summary:
By Patrick Wall, Chalkbeat NewarkOriginally published on Friday, April 10The Newark school district is delaying the release of school matches by more than a month, leaving thousands of families to wait several extra weeks to learn which schools their children will attend this fall.
Families who applied to any traditional school and certain charter schools in Newark were due to find out Sunday where students had been placed.
However, a note tucked away on the district's enrollment website says matches will not be released on schedule because of the coronavirus pandemic.
Families were scheduled to receive school matches on April 12, but the release has been postponed.
Each year, families and students anxiously await their school matches, which the district determines based on each family's preferences and other factors, including available seats and students' special needs.

title: Aroostook airports receive federal funding to aid costs during virus
summary:
(Joseph Cyr | Houlton Pioneer Times)Aroostook airports receive federal funding to aid costs during virusFour airports in Aroostook County are among the 35 in Maine that will receive millions in federal funding to sustain operations during the COVID-19 pandemic.
AROOSTOOK COUNTY, Maine — Four airports in Aroostook County are among the 35 in Maine that will receive millions in federal funding to sustain operations during the COVID-19 pandemic.
The Federal Aviation Administration announced on Tuesday that Presque Isle International Airport will receive $1 million.
Caribou Municipal Airport and Northern Aroostook Regional Airport in Frenchville will receive $20,000 each and Houlton International Airport will receive $30,000.

title: Georgia man ran COVID-19 testing fraud scheme, federal investigators say
summary:
NEWARK, N.J. — FBI agents arrested a Braselton, Ga., man on Monday after federal investigators said he allegedly worked to submit fraudulent testing claims for COVID-19 and genetic cancer screenings, authorities said.
According to the US District Attorney's Office of New Jersey, Santos allegedly got kickbacks from medically unnecessary testing, including testing for the COVID-19 coronavirus, which is already scarce in the United States.
Officials said Santos ran a marketing company that would help send people to certain testing companies.
He, and others, received kickback payments from the companies involved in the testing, the cost of which was being reimbursed by Medicare, prosecutors said.
Santos, prosecutors said, would be paid on a per-test basis for submitting genetic cancer screening tests, regardless of medical necessity.

title: Here’s where N.J.’s low-snow winter ranks as February fades away
summary:
New Jersey’s strange, almost snowless winter season isn’t over yet.
That distinction belongs to the unrivaled winter of 1972-1973, when only 4 inches of snow fell in the Garden State during the entire snow season — which runs from October through April.
Another low-snow winter occurred in 1918-1919, with just 4.2 inches of frozen precipitation accumulating across the state, according to Robinson.

“I’m not about to declare the snow season over, as March and early April can see snow,” Robinson said.

title: Republicans Are Trying to Kick Thousands of Voters Off the Rolls During a Pandemic
summary:
Roll ReversalsBetween 2016 and 2018, more than 17 million names were taken off voter rolls nationwide.
Wisconsin: 14% of voters removed, 2016-18In 2017, Wisconsin officials mailed postcards to 340,000 registered voters thought to have moved, informing them that they would be removed from voter rolls if they did not respond.
Oklahoma: 11.7% of voters removed, 2016-18Oklahoma’s “use-it-or-lose-it” voter registration law means voters are purged if they don’t vote for several election cycles and don’t respond to a mailing.
From 2016 to 2018, 17 million Americans—8 percent of the nation’s electorate—were taken off the voting rolls, according to the Brennan Center for Justice.

title: Who’s to blame for Florida’s coronavirus problems? DeSantis points to other states.
summary:
This week, as Florida’s coronavirus numbers skyrocketed, DeSantis turned the pointed finger at other states for fueling the growing public health menace.
“After all the hard work, we don’t want it to now get seeded as people flee the hot zone,” DeSantis said.

Newark Mayor Ras Baraka announced Thursday that, due to growing concerns about COVID-19 and the health and safety of the people of Newark, he is advising that all non-essential public gatherings be canceled for the next 30 days, according to a release.
The release also said Baraka’s State of the City address, originally scheduled for next Monday, has been postponed for at least 30 days.
According to the release, a “non-essential group event” is defined as a gathering of 250 people or more for social, cultural or entertainment events where people are not separated by physical space of at least 4 feet.

title: Newark and New Jersey officials continue to dissemble about statewide lead poisoning crisis
summary:
Newark and New Jersey officials continue to dissemble about statewide lead poisoning crisisBy Shuvu Batta21 October 2019Earlier this month, the results of testing conducted in Newark, New Jersey’s public schools in August 2018 were released, showing that seven schools have lead-contaminated water.
Most lead service lines were installed before 1940.
New Jersey’s governor, Democrat and multi-millionaire Goldman Sachs alumnus Phil Murphy, has unveiled a proposal to replace all lead service lines in the state by 2029.

title: Here's Why It Was So Darn Hot This September In NJ, Expert Says
summary:
With average temperatures of 69 degrees, September 2019 is tied for the eighth-warmest on record, coming in at 3.3 degrees above the 1981-2010 average, according to Rutgers University professor David Robinson.
Southern areas of the state were the warmest, at 3.5 degrees above average, while the north was 2.8 degrees above average.
Robinson, the New Jersey state climatologist, also said last month was the sixth-driest September in 125 years, with the state averaging a meager 1.19 inches of precipitation… 2.86 below the 1981-2010 average.
In addition, New Jersey's baseline temperatures are warming due to the overall global warming associated with increased greenhouse gases.

title: N.J. weather: Another coastal storm to hit region with heavy rain, strong winds
summary:

title: Newark Says Water Crisis Is Easing as Lead Filters Prove Mostly Effective

title: Thousands of children in New Jersey found to have elevated blood lead levels

Thousands of children in New Jersey found to have elevated blood lead levelsBy Erik Schreiber10 December 2019About 4,500 children in New Jersey had an elevated level of lead in their blood during fiscal 2018, according to a report by the state’s department of health.
In New Jersey’s largest cities, particularly those with large working-class populations, the proportion of children with elevated blood lead levels was found to be as high as 6.4 percent.
In previous years, New Jersey used a threshold of 10 micrograms per deciliter (μg/dl) to define an elevated blood lead level.
The counties with the highest prevalence of children under age six with elevated blood lead levels were Salem (5.6 percent), Warren (4.8 percent), Essex (4.1 percent), Cumberland (3.9 percent), and Mercer (3.9 percent).

Santos, prosecutors said, would be paid on a per-test basis for submitting genetic cancer screening tests, regardless of medical necessity.

title: Republicans Are Trying to Kick Thousands of Voters Off the Rolls During a Pandemic
summary:
Roll ReversalsBetween 2016 and 2018, more than 17 million names were taken off voter rolls nationwide.
Wisconsin: 14% of voters removed, 2016-18In 2017, Wisconsin officials mailed postcards to 340,000 registered voters thought to have moved, informing them that they would be removed from voter rolls if they did not respond.
Oklahoma: 11.7% of voters removed, 2016-18Oklahoma’s “use-it-or-lose-it” voter registration law means voters are purged if they don’t vote for several election cycles and don’t respond to a mailing.
From 2016 to 2018, 17 million Americans—8 percent of the nation’s electorate—were taken off the voting rolls, according to the Brennan Center for Justice.

title: Southwest Airlines to cease flights from Newark airport
summary:

“The financial results at Newark have been below expectations, despite the efforts of our excellent team at Newark,” Southwest chairman and CEO Gary C. Kelly said in a statement.
Southwest says the airline's approximately 125 employees at Newark are being offered positions at LaGuardia or can bid for other jobs elsewhere.
The airline currently has about 15 departures a day from Newark airport to destinations including Chicago, Nashville, Austin, Denver, Phoenix and St. Louis.

title: Newark Says Water Crisis Is Easing as Lead Filters Prove Mostly Effective
summary:
NEWARK — Officials in New Jersey’s largest city announced on Monday that thousands of water filters handed out to residents had significantly reduced lead in drinking water to safe levels.
Bottled water would still be made available, but officials said the crisis that had gripped the city for months seemed to be easing.
Testing done jointly by city, state and federal officials found that the filters had been 97 percent effective at reducing lead levels to below a federally acceptable standard, meaning that 97 percent of test results showed the filters working properly.
“These results are a welcome jolt of positive news that allows us collectively to charge ahead in implementing our short-term, midterm and long-term solutions,” Gov.

title: Bank failure in New Jersey is nation's third in a week
summary:

City National Bank of New Jersey was shuttered by the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, which appointed the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. as receiver.
City National’s operations were sold to Industrial Bank in Washington, D.C. Industrial is a unit of IBW Financial.
Industrial, which is also a minority depository institution, agreed to buy essentially all of City National's assets and assume all of the failed bank’s deposits.
All three of City National’s existing branches will reopen Saturday under Industrial’s ownership.

title: Newark Cops Disarm Man At Gas Station On New Year's Eve (VIDEO)
summary:
NEWARK, NJ — A trio of Newark police officers defused a potentially deadly encounter on New Year's Eve, showing "great restraint" while arresting a man with a handgun at a gas station, authorities said.
When the officers arrived at the gas station, they came across two men who were having a loud argument.

title: Belleville’s Chinatown, the First on the East Coast
summary:
Belleville’s Chinatown was an ethnic and socioeconomic municipal powerhouse that radiated influence throughout the Garden State.
In the second half of the 19th century, Chinese workers were the backbone of those who helped stretch America’s railroad network from coast to coast after the Civil War.
Belleville Mayor Michael Melham notes that many people don’t know that by 1870, more than 10% of Belleville’s population was Chinese, living in the first thriving Chinatown on the East Coast of the U.S.
The monument is dedicated by the United Chinese American Association of New Jersey, and is currently framed by both a Christmas wreath and an American flag.
But the first Chinatown on the East Coast that they created in Belleville resonates far beyond their numbers, including among their Italian American neighbors living just blocks away.

title: Frontier expanding to Newark, New Jersey, with 15 nonstop flights and $15 fares
summary:
Buzz60Frontier Airlines plans to begin service in Newark, New Jersey, in November, capitalizing on Southwest Airlines' looming exit.
Frontier will offer daily nonstop flights between Newark and 15 cities, including Las Vegas; Orlando, Florida; Phoenix; Atlanta; Chicago; and Dallas, executives announced Tuesday.
Rapidly growing Frontier Airlines is expanding to Newark, New Jersey (Photo: Frontier Airlines)Tickets for seven of the cities go on sale today on Frontier's website, with introductory fares starting at $15 one-way on most routes for Tuesday and Wednesday travel.
Frontier, which already serves Trenton, New Jersey, and Philadelphia, in the region, will still be a small player at Newark.
And Frontier won't be the only budget airline there: Spirit Airlines also offers Newark flights.

title: Republicans Are Trying to Kick Thousands of Voters Off the Rolls During a Pandemic
summary:
Roll ReversalsBetween 2016 and 2018, more than 17 million names were taken off voter rolls nationwide.
Wisconsin: 14% of voters removed, 2016-18In 2017, Wisconsin officials mailed postcards to 340,000 registered voters thought to have moved, informing them that they would be removed from voter rolls if they did not respond.
Oklahoma: 11.7% of voters removed, 2016-18Oklahoma’s “use-it-or-lose-it” voter registration law means voters are purged if they don’t vote for several election cycles and don’t respond to a mailing.
From 2016 to 2018, 17 million Americans—8 percent of the nation’s electorate—were taken off the voting rolls, according to the Brennan Center for Justice.
Last year, Judicial Watch reached a settlement with California to reassess 1.5 million names on the voter rolls in Los Angeles County.
